intro: Acaena sanguisorbae subsp. epoligotricha, commonly known as the red burr bush, is a flowering plant species native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its distinctive, spiny, red-brown fruits that contain seeds. The plant typically grows in coastal and subalpine regions, thriving in well-drained soils. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and often covered with fine hairs. The species is part of the rose family (Rosaceae) and is known for its ecological importance in supporting local wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena sanguisorbae subsp. epoligotricha is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the North Island and parts of the South Island. This subspecies typically grows in coastal and inland areas, often in rocky or gravelly soils. It is commonly associated with coastal dunes and heathlands. The plant is well adapted to the temperate climate and can tolerate salt spray in coastal regions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena sanguisorbae subsp. epoligotricha was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. This subspecies is commonly found in disturbed soils and open habitats. It has become naturalized in various regions of the country. However, it is not considered a major invasive species in New Zealand.
